title: Gameplay for deaf players
body:
Hi,

I was playing a game with an enemy Sion and when I heard him ult towards botlane I knew to retreat.  However, his ult's telegraphing via scream might not be heard by well, the deaf players of our community.  I think this is an unfair advantage unless there was some option to create a visual for his ult or something.

Thoughts?

Literally 2 seconds after I posted I forgot about Rek'sai's ult too, basically any skill that's telegraphed through noise

replies.body: Although I'm sure they would appreciate it, I'm also pretty sure deaf people have gotten over not hearing things.

> [{quoted}](name=Fawezome,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=VVJJ5EYe,comment-id=0003,timestamp=2015-02-06T08:50:49.987+0000)
>
> Although I'm sure they would appreciate it, I'm also pretty sure deaf people have gotten over not hearing things.

Not a reason to not add a little something to the screen especially if Riot can code this quickly.

You know, sometimes people play with their speakers off?
This is not just for deaf people.

Really like this idea, as it could also help players who dislike the global ultimate sounds from both of these champions to mute those individual game sounds, yet still know when a champion has ulted. 

Something as simple as a small design appearing in the top right corner of your screen for both Sion and Rek'Sai could represent when they've used their ultimates.
Or a border, like you may see a purple haze on the edge of the screen (like the classic "low heath red haze" effect, but a different color) for a second or so.

> [{quoted}](name=Unlimited Gin,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=VVJJ5EYe,comment-id=00020000,timestamp=2015-02-06T16:39:21.173+0000)
>
> Or a border, like you may see a purple haze on the edge of the screen (like the classic "low heath red haze" effect, but a different color) for a second or so.

Color has the problem that color blind people might not see it correctly. A little graphic in the corner of the screen is better I think. Like an angry Sion's head or something ;)
Well but what are the odds of someone being colorblind and deaf? Can't be that many in our comunity
Why not implement something that works with everybody though? The main causes of problems in the game would be eye,  motor or sound related so if they do something let's do the best solution.

> [{quoted}](name=Gorbache,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=VVJJ5EYe,comment-id=00020000000000000000,timestamp=2015-02-06T21:54:08.251+0000)
>
> Why not implement something that works with everybody though? The main causes of problems in the game would be eye,  motor or sound related so if they do something let's do the best solution.

A little graphic on the corner of the skin is easily miss able. Specially where you mostly focus on your skills cds and on the minimap. The graphic most likely will be on the top right corner (where events and quest appears) How many times do you check that specific part of the screen? 

You could just give a red admiration mark on top of the player. Sorta like rengars ult since technically you are on range, but then if you hae a rek sai and rengar on the same team you wouldn't know which ult is which.
Some people play without sound too (i.e. playing at school) and there ARE many colorblind folks in my college.

Hi there, I do agree that the deaf or hard of hearing players in the League of Legends community has a slight disadvantage when it comes to sound or audio. I was born deaf, so I definitely know what it is like to get caught by something unexpected, like getting hit by Sion's ultimate or Rek'Sai coming out of nowhere after he recalled to base. However, only a tiny amount of champions sends a message to all players once a certain ability is used, so it is not a glaring issue as of now. I'm sure this problem will rise again when more champions with similar telegraphing abilites are released in the future. 

For players who are deaf like myself, the best thing to do is to be aware of that certain champion by looking at the map. If Sion or Rek'Sai is MIA, always be cautious and be ready while looking at the minimap.

A few other champions while not having a global sound do have a phrase or something they say, that anyone nearby can hear, when they're about to do something major. Karma's phrase when she activates her R comes to mind. As a former Karma main I know that's the time to back off cause she's about to do something crazy.

I'm pretty sure there's a few others, but Riot has done a good job of making sure there's always visual cues for things. Karma's has a cue but it's easy to miss in most skirmishes and fights.

Ah I see.  I guess a minuscule disadvantage can be overcome with a bit more to be aware of;  I am worried about later champions being released with those kinds of telegraphing functions, however.  These are relatively new champions here, and I'm assuming Riot is trying to use sound effects to balance out abilities with near global influence more.  It's just something I figured Riot and the community should be aware of

Okay, I'll have to say it this way because of the fact I've been around and known many hearing challenged people. Yes, it's nice to think we can do it for the hearing impaired, but it would make the natural hearing have an extra advantage also. Hearing impaired people have to compensate for everyday life, whether or not we realize it. They make innovations for themselves. They compensate. Some play with hearing people so they can gives cue's for the ult sounds. Like f = fiddle ult s = sion ult r= reksai ult ect. Hearing impaired move on in their own stride, and do not like to think of themselves as impaired. Do not make a special game mode just for that. 

However, having CC (closed caption) as an option is a good concept. It's the only thing for people who are hearing impaired that I and probably they, would accept. It also has noises included. *Crows* *Clang* *Screeching* That would be nice, and far better than making changes to the entire gameplay. That way, hearing impaired and non can have the option.
Most important thing is that it doesn't show where Sion is ulting from or to. In other words, don't nerf the champions because of this.
Who said anything about nerfing them?? :o
Logic. Logic said something.

Or, perhaps, nobody said anything about it? It's to my understanding they just want some form of notification for those with sound off or who are deaf and have no way of knowing about the ult. That's entirely different from nerfing them to show where they're coming from or where they're going.

Is it entirely different if the means to visually signal Sion's ultimate to deaf people gives away the direction Sion is coming from or going to? If you actually think about it, a nerf of this manner can be an unintended result of a solution to the original problem. Just like how a nerf to mana regeneration was a buff to manaless champions.

Given that you couldn't see how the two concepts are related, I would say the mention of this possible result was worth YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED's time.

How will it give away the direction? It's just a notifier somewhere on the screen. You can't tell where s/he's coming from when you can hear it, so why would they make it so you can SEE where they're coming from? OP just asked for some way for those who are deaf - or another circumstance being with the sound off - to be able to tell when it was activated. Never did they state for the champions to be able to be seen on the minimap at any time.

I am WELL aware of what the OP said. I am WELL aware of what an effective solution might look like. What you're not WELL aware of is that the solution COULD give away the direction.  All that's been said is that it SHOULDN'T.
It's an opinion on another possible solution to the aforementioned problem, not an opinion on the most apparent and effective solution.
You asked who mentioned that possibility and I said logic did.
Logic is not a forum member, in my usage of the word.

I would make a red outline appear on the screen of players within running range of Sion's ultimate for a split second.
Same with Rek'sai, but instead maybe a purple outline to all players for a split second.
Putting something on the screen makes it even MORE obvious when something is happening. It's a nerf to Sion etc.

I'm not deaf myself, so I can only speak with a second-hand opinion on this, but I think it would be nice to have some kind of intelligent closed captioning for dialogue and sound effects, so perhaps on-screen indicators when {{champion:14}} or {{champion:421}} are ulting, but also perhaps screen-oriented captions for other sound effects. Sound is important in locating opponents, guessing their attacks, and figuring out if your abilities hit a target, so not being able to experience it at all likely creates a gameplay disadvantage. Looking at some "just for fun" fan videos of League of Legends, there's often some kind of dynamic text edited onto champions or abilities to illustrate the sound they're making, and the ideal would probably be to have a sort of automatic version of this that mimics the sounds and cues hearing players experience.
I actually play with sound off and put my own music in the background. Didn't know the game sounds made such a difference.

There's also a large number of skill shots that only have audio ques.  Noc's Q comes to mind, where if you hit an enemy in the bush, it makes a noise, but there is otherwise no notification unless they move and spread the trail.  Unfortunately, this is not a simple undertaking.  

There's a ton of spells that have audio feedback but no visual feedback if the enemy is in fog of war.  You'd need to go through and Identify each of them to start, and with 123 champions in the game, that's a lot of stuff.  

I don't know what their back end is like, but it sounds like at this point, they have a fuckton of modular building blocks, so adding the assets **should** be easy.  

The trouble is making the assets.  For every spell that needs to have visual feedback, there's design overhead to figure out what kind of feedback they want, specifically.  It'll take potentially several iterations of design and art coming up with what they want it to do and look like, as well as polishing the quality once they get it how they want it.  There's likely to be bugs generated as well, and QA time needs to be allocated for each feature added.

This is just for small things like a skillshot into a bush.  Figuring out what to do with rek sai and sion is another matter.  It may be wise to implement a 'deaf mode' similar to color blind mode, but that would involve additional code work, and a plethora of bugs.
This is a really nice idea, but it would need to be done in such a way as to not reduce the power of those champions by giving a greater advantage to players who aren't deaf.

Had not considered this - it's an interesting problem. I've got a friend who always plays with the sound muted, and it drives me insane. "Why didn't you get out of Sion's ult dude? We heard the sound!" - "There's a SOUND?"
I agree it is a disadvantage.
People play with game sound on?
